title: Crypt0Gore
author: Crypt0Gore
content: I want to correct some people on here thinking that the involvement of politics/politicians with Bitcoin makes it mainstream, they are wrong, mainstream is a gradual process and we are not there yet.The first part was when everyone, weak or powerful are doubting if bitcoin will survive, this was the early days of Bitcoin when we can mine using a Pentium 4 CPU to mine BTC.The second part was when many popular figure started talking trash about Bitcoin, atleast they started saying something, until they slowly start to detect how incredible Bitcoin really is, and few changed their mind about Bitcoin.The third part is the struggle with centralisation vs decentralisation, banks and co hating on Bitcoin, mind you this happened only because loads of people started showing more interest in Bitcoin than centralised investments, especially the banks.Now the bigger companies starts investing in Bitcoin, ETF came and the politicians are proving to support Bitcoin, maybe for the greater good or just for power struggle, these aren't the real mainstream yet. We are almost there, the acceptance of Bitcoin as a medium of exchange in this centralized world is the goal, the real mainstream, having Bitcoin as a payment option around the world is the real definition of mainstream, the moment Amazon, eBay, and others online marketplaces start accepting Bitcoin as they do with Fiat is the mainstream.The full-fledged acceptance of Bitcoin everywhere is the true meaning of mainstream.

comments.author: TheUltraElite
comments.body: Quote from: Crypt0Gore on September 09, 2024, 11:02:18 AMThe full-fledged acceptance of Bitcoin everywhere is the true meaning of mainstream. When we use the term "mainstream" we mean the shifting of a concept from "Niche" to "Mainstream" - when that concept is everywhere in the world, it is not longer niche or mainstream but a part of our lives. What you have meant to say is this.Anyway this will take time to be reached and maybe most of us here will not be lucky enough to see that day. I already see a co-existence of bitcoin and fiat being built up and that is the progress of bitcoin and its acceptance throughout the word.Maybe something later we will be able to pay every local grocery shop with satoshis.

comments.author: BitcoinBarrel
comments.body: Nothing is ever fully-accepted everywhere...Bitcoin is about as mainstream as it gets. Even my grandma knows about it.

comments.author: Blitzboy
comments.body: I concur completely. A process, not an overnight change. All the indications are there. The narrative is evolving as big players join. Everything's exciting. You know what? This goes beyond Bitcoin. This is about human transformation management. We start doubtful, then interested, then maybe afraid. This dance has been around since the beginning.Bitcoin differs. It goes beyond fads. It changes our view of money and worth. Its powerful because of that. There will be politicians and big money. Only the top of the iceberg. Change is happening at the grassroots level. People use, trust, and believe in Bitcoin. It'll become mainstream with that. It will be more than another investing opportunity. It will be habitual. It will alter reality.

comments.author: mindrust
comments.body: Bitcoin is mainstream. There isn't a single person who doesn't heard of it anymore. Everybody knows about it and everybody has a chance to get in. We are not early adopters anymore. Bitcoin is almost as big as gold in terms of market cap. If that doesn't make it mainstream, I don't know what else does. Politicians talk about bitcoin because they can't ignore it. They know if they get the support of the bitcoiners, it will have a positive impact on the election results for them.

comments.author: Moreno233
comments.body: Quote from: Crypt0Gore on September 09, 2024, 11:02:18 AMThe full-fledged acceptance of Bitcoin everywhere is the true meaning of mainstream.There will rarely come a time when Bitcoin will be accepted everywhere because that will be saying that the global population will be well educated and possibly computer literate. We know how impossible this is. As of today, there are still people not connected to the internet, no access to electricity and no form of civilization. How do these people know about Bitcoin and how to use it when they do not have electricity and internet? On the other hand, there are people that will always refuse to use Bitcoin even after knowing about it with reasons such as security, being used to their traditional understanding of money and many others. I have a few of them around and you can never convince them to use Bitcoin as they prefer fiat.

(which seems this is really them?  )

comments.author: Apocollapse
comments.body: Quote from: Crypt0Gore on September 09, 2024, 11:02:18 AMWe are almost there, the acceptance of Bitcoin as a medium of exchange in this centralized world is the goalThat's the goal for most people excluding myself. I don't like to see Bitcoin become a medium of exchange in centralized world because it will make Bitcoin less decentralized. This also could make Bitcoin become centralized if all coins are owned by few institutions or people.I'd like to see Bitcoin become decentralized rather than trade the value for money.

comments.author: Alpha Marine
comments.body: I don't even seem to understand why Bitcoiners are excited about this kind of news. These were people that have condemned Bitcoin in the past and it had no impact on bitcoin but now they have accepted bitcoin they believe it will have an impact on bitcoin. I don't know if it's the fact that I'm always sceptical of politicians and billionaires that have made me not give a shit about what they say, but I just don't think it holds any water. A politician saying he'll do this or that if elected is something I've been hearing all my life, so that kind of talk doesn't move me even when it's related to bitcoin because I know that all he wants is votes. A tech billionaire will build an app and say something like "We respect your privacy and would never share your personal details with a third party" and people will believe that. How? Is he expected to say "We will share your personal details with the government if you use our app"? Hell say what the potential customers want to hear and that's exactly the same thing politicians do, they say what voters want to hear.

comments.author: AVE5
comments.body: Quote from: Crypt0Gore on September 09, 2024, 11:02:18 AMI want to correct some people on here thinking that the involvement of politics/politicians with Bitcoin makes it mainstream, they are wrong, mainstream is a gradual process and we are not there yet.Bitcoin hasn't been involved of gaining its contentments with the political harmonization instead it's been diluted by the politicians simply because the bitcoin is built in a decentralized system that's off the control of the politicians as a government.I'd rather say that highily rich individuals who might be politicians, stock investors and even institutes who adopted the use of bitcoin from the earlier age has played interesting role to mainstream of bitcoin which has really attracted the average individuals to follow up.The speculations of bitcoin such as market predictions and public awarenesses has also advent to the mainstream of bitcoin.Interestingly to say that bitcoin mainstream isn't directed at the arrival of a particular sector or jurisdiction but of all that has displayed awareness to the significance of its broad recognitions and values.However, we're yet to arrive at an advanced stage with more factors referring to bitcoin mainstream.

comments.author: Dunamisx
comments.body: Quote from: Crypt0Gore on September 09, 2024, 11:02:18 AMThe full-fledged acceptance of Bitcoin everywhere is the true meaning of mainstream.Of course its upon this in which it value is being placed, the general availability of bitcoin being a decentralized digital currency, its ability to overcome inflationary effect, it profitability and acceptance as an asset of investment, because bitcoin has been seen as a profitable asset, whereby we have to realize its uniqueness over the financial economy, whereby every sectors are willing to set their support in adopting it at all cost, we can see this also as a manifest from the increasing daily adoption we have with bitcoin all over the world.

comments.author: MeGold666
comments.body: I don't want to break your enthusiasm but Bitcoin has big scalability issues and it's usage as medium of exchange has been dropping for years now while LN that was promised to fix it failed miserably with it's own set of scalability issues.Bitcoin will never be used as payment option on larger scale because it's too slow and too expensive to use, there are much faster and cheaper options.I have talked about it in other thread: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5499690.msg64498097#msg64498097

comments.author: avikz
comments.body: Bitcoin looks great as a niche payment method. Making it mainstream will loose its decentralized nature where banks and government will become a part of the ecosystem. Honestly, I don't want to see Bitcoin becoming too mainstream. It will not help in the growth of Bitcoin in any way, rather the network will become too clogged that a transaction will either become too expensive or too slow. Bitcoin is great as a parallel currency system as it is now. This is mainstream to me. Some people will disagree but I think Bitcoin is not capable of handling the volume that a mainstream payment processor can handle with ease. It needs upgrade and a solution to its scaling issue.

It's pathetic.Bitcoin would never even come to life if everyone was such a P***Y in the first place.As of today the biggest problem of Bitcoin is it's community who forgot what this is all about.

comments.author: EL MOHA
comments.body: Quote from: mindrust on September 09, 2024, 01:38:46 PMBitcoin is mainstream. There isn't a single person who doesn't heard of it anymore. Everybody knows about it and everybody has a chance to get in. We are not early adopters anymore. Bitcoin is almost as big as gold in terms of market cap. If that doesn't make it mainstream, I don't know what else does.Actually the phrase which is usually said that we are early adopters isn’t wrong if used correctly, for example the bitcoin word has spread round and almost every corner of the world knows or have heard of bitcoin but are they convinced that they invested in it? I don’t think so, if I can estimate I will say only one-third of the people that have heard about bitcoin have actually invested which means that they are earlier. Another reason to say that we are early is the price of bitcoin. comments.author: swogerino
comments.body: Mainstream as a notion to me means that something is mainstream in this matter regarding currencies when you can use it everywhere. We are quite far in this notion regarding Bitcoin going mainstream as we cannot use it anywhere relevant in the world, by relevant I mean international online markets like Ebay or Amazon, as long as there is no sign with paying in Bitcoin I doubt we can say that we are there yet. For me we will be there when in every local supermarket there will be qr codes that allow us to pay in Bitcoin through our phones but again we are very far from that worldwide speaking.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Quote from: Crypt0Gore on September 09, 2024, 11:02:18 AM~snip~We are almost there, the acceptance of Bitcoin as a medium of exchange in this centralized world is the goal, the real mainstream, having Bitcoin as a payment option around the world is the real definition of mainstream, the moment Amazon, eBay, and others online marketplaces start accepting Bitcoin as they do with Fiat is the mainstream.I will only refer to this part because I believe that the acceptance of Bitcoin as a means of payment by these large companies would have very little effect (in the long term) on how that same Bitcoin is perceived by what we call the mainstream. I see the reason for this in the fact that in the past we had some companies that accepted BTC as a means of payment, but after some time these same companies gave up on the same, not only because of volatility, but primarily because that payment option was used by very few number of clients. The problem (if we can call it that) is actually that a very small percentage of people actually want to spend BTC on something because they invested in it exclusively for profit. In addition, many will find it very complicated to pay with BTC, of ​​course compared to paying with cards or cash.
